docs.title: Welcome to Aurynk
docs.text:
Wirelessly connect, manage and control your Android devices from Linux

Aurynk (Aura + Sync, pronounced “aw-rink”) makes managing your Android devices from Linux simple and wireless. No more cables, no more complicated setup - just scan a QR code and you're connected!

Perfect for: - 📱 Developers testing apps on multiple devices - 🎮 Gamers managing Android gaming setups - 👨‍💻 Power users who want full device control - 📸 Content creators capturing device screenshots

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• :material-qrcode-scan: Wireless Pairing --- Connect via QR code - no cables needed! Just scan and go.

  • :material-cellphone-information: Device Management --- View detailed specs, battery life, and storage info at a glance.

  • :material-camera: Screenshot Capture --- Instantly capture and save device screenshots to your PC.

  • :material-monitor-cellphone: Screen Mirroring --- View and control your device screen (powered by scrcpy).

  • :material-palette: Modern Interface --- Beautiful GTK4 design that fits your Linux desktop perfectly.

  • :material-devices: Multiple Devices --- Manage several Android devices simultaneously.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Check out the Installation guide to get Aurynk running on your machine.

docs.title: Contributing to Aurynk
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to Aurynk! This document provides all the technical information developers need to contribute to the project.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Runtime Dependencies

  • Python 3.11 or newer
  • GTK 4
  • libadwaita 1.0 or newer
  • PyGObject
  • Android Debug Bridge (adb)

Build Dependencies

  • Meson (>= 0.59.0)
  • Ninja
  • GLib development files
  • GTK4 development files

docs.title: Setting up the Environment
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/IshuSinghSE/aurynk.git
cd aurynk

  2. Install system dependencies:

    Ubuntu/DebianFedoraArch 
    sudo apt install python3-dev python3-gi gir1.2-gtk-4.0 gir1.2-adw-1 \
                 android-tools-adb meson ninja-build

    sudo dnf install python3-devel python3-gobject gtk4-devel libadwaita-devel \
                 android-tools meson ninja-build

    sudo pacman -S python python-gobject gtk4 libadwaita android-tools meson ninja

  3. Install Python dependencies: 

    # Create virtual environment (recommended)
python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # or `.venv/bin/activate.fish` for Fish shell

# Install project with dev dependencies
pip install -e ".[dev]"

  4. Compile GResources: 

    glib-compile-resources --sourcedir=data data/io.github.IshuSinghSE.aurynk.gresource.xml \
    --target=data/io.github.IshuSinghSE.aurynk.gresource

  5. Run the application: 

    python -m aurynk

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository on GitHub.
  2. Create a feature branch from main.
  3. Make your changes following the code style guidelines.
  4. Test your changes thoroughly.
  5. Commit with descriptive messages.
  6. Push to your fork and create a Pull Request.

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
This project uses ruff for linting and formatting.

# Check code style
ruff check .

# Format code
ruff format .

docs.title: Packaging
docs.text: The project supports various packaging formats, including Flatpak, Debian, and Snap. Check the flatpak/ and debian/ directories for manifest files.

docs.title: Features
docs.text: Aurynk provides a comprehensive suite of tools for Android device management.

docs.title: :material-qrcode-scan: Wireless Pairing
docs.text:
Forget about USB cables. Aurynk uses the modern Wireless Debugging protocol introduced in Android 11.

  1. Open Aurynk.
  2. Click Add Device.
  3. On your phone, go to Developer Options > Wireless Debugging > Pair device with QR code.
  4. Scan the code displayed in Aurynk.
  5. Done!

docs.title: :material-monitor-cellphone: Screen Mirroring
docs.text:
Powered by the robust scrcpy tool, Aurynk allows low-latency, high-quality screen mirroring.

  • Control: Use your mouse and keyboard to control your Android device.
  • Performance: High performance and low latency.
  • Configurable: Adjust bitrate, resolution, and more in Settings.

docs.title: :material-camera: Screenshot Manager
docs.text:
Take high-quality screenshots of your device screen directly from your desktop.

  • One-click capture.
  • Saved directly to your Linux machine.
  • Preview and manage screenshots within the app.

docs.title: :material-tune: Device Dashboard
docs.text:
Get a quick overview of your device health and stats.

  • Battery Level: Monitor charging status and percentage.
  • Storage: See available and used space.
  • Details: View Android version, model, and manufacturer info.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Aurynk is available for various Linux distributions. The recommended way to install is via Flatpak.

docs.title: Option 1: Flatpak (Recommended) :star:
docs.text:
Aurynk is available on Flathub for easy installation. This ensures you have all dependencies isolated and up to date.

flatpak install flathub io.github.IshuSinghSE.aurynk

docs.title: Option 2: From GitHub Release
docs.text:
You can download pre-built packages from our GitHub Releases page.

  1. Download the latest release from GitHub Releases
  2. Install using your package manager:
Debian/UbuntuFlatpak Bundle 
sudo dpkg -i aurynk_*.deb

flatpak install aurynk_*.flatpak

docs.title: Option 3: Build from Source
docs.text: If you are a developer or want to build the latest version from source, please check our Contributing Guide.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
To use Aurynk's wireless features effectively, you need:

  1. A computer running Linux.
  2. An Android device (Android 11+ recommended for Wireless Debugging).
  3. Both devices connected to the same WiFi network.
